titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ghassem Ghani collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Manuscripts and Archives Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:06

did.unittitle: Ghassem Ghani collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: A collection of Persian manuscripts dating from the nineteenth century and consisting largely of official correspondence and reports to the Shah of Iran.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ghassem Ghani Collection (MS 235). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Series I-V and VII-IX are also available on microfilm (751 frames on 1 reel, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University, at cost. Order no. HM25.

item.ref: SERIES III - A The Letters of AmÄ«r Kabir from No. 1 to 210.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of Persian manuscripts dating from the nineteenth century and consisting largely of official correspondence and reports to the Shah of Iran.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Series I
1. Haji Mirza Aqasi (chancellor of Mohammad Shah) to Manuchehr Khan Motamed-od-Dowleh (Governor of Isfahan) Concerning a dispute between Abdol Hosein Khan and Ibzahim Khan over agricultural property.
2. Haji-Mirza Aqasi to Mohammad Shah (Shah of Iran). Concerning the conversation between Mirza Djafar Khan and Russian Prince Vorontzov.
3. Same to Same. Assuring the Shah that there are no symptoms of any new disease in the Harem.
4. Same to Same. Expressing sorrow that the Moslems are not concerned with the conquest and subordination of the nonbelievers.
5. Same to Same. Prays that God may not remove the shadow of the Shah from the heads of the people of Iran.
6. Same to Same. Concerning the Russian General Perovski and the chaos in the Persian army.
7. Same to Same. In defence of a court official who was criticized by the Shah.
8. Same to Same. Thanking the Shah for his concern over his health.
9. Same to Same. Inviting the Shah to Abbas AbÄd for rest.
10. Same to Same. Concerning his health.
11. Same to Same. Concerning two letters written six years previously to two foreign envoys which were never delivered to them.
12. Same to Same. Complaining about the brothers and the uncles of the Shah who are involved in intrigues and treason.
13. Same to Same. Complaining about the foreigners (Europeans) who have caused him pain and suffering.
14. Same to Same. A routine report.
15. Same to Same. Concerning the necessity of the Shah's presence in the capitol.
16. FarhÄd MirzÄto Bibi Jan. Sending a Koran to her.
17. Koluke, Shah's physician, to the Shah. Concerning the mineral waters of Larsidjan.
18. HÄji Mirza Aqasi to the Shah. Concerning some diseases in the city and the suburbs (of Teheran).
19. Farhad Murza to Sepah-Salar Aáº"am: Concerning the mutiny of some soldiers and their punishment.
20. A note by Farhad Mirza (then the governor of Teheran): Consulted Hafez (Persian poet whose verses are used for telling fortunes).
21. Farhad Mirza to Assef-od-Dowleh: Complaining of sickness and old age.
22. Mirza Abbas Khan Muaven-of-Molk: Inquiring after the health of Amin-od-Dowleh.
23. Mirza Abbas Khan Muaven-of-Molk: Inquiring after the health of Amin-od-Dowleh.
24. Hesam-os-Saltaneh-to Sadra-od-Dowleh: Confirming the receipt of a package of tea.
25. Same to Same: Concerning his estates in Isfahan.
26. Same to Same: Continuation of No. 25.
27. Mirza Ussof Mostashar-od-Dowleh to Aqa Gafar (a merchant): Sending a money order for the price of a book.
28. Safi Ali Shah to Abdol Ali Mirza: Confirming the receipt of a pair of glasses.
29. Same to Same: Inquiring about his health.
30. Malkam Khan to (addressee unknown): Criticizing the lack of security in Iran (dated July 26, 1906).
31. A note by Farhad Mirza (dated 1295 A.H.).
32. Egbal-od-Dowleh Kash?to Naser-os-Saltaneh: A routine letter.
33. Safi Ali Shah to (addressee unknown): Concerning the survivors of Nosrat-os-Saltaneh who are in need.
34. Abdul-Ali-Mirza to his daughter Zahra Khanum: Concerning the expenses of the house.
35. Masud-Mirza Zell-os-Soltan (the Shah's son) to Saheb Ekhtiaz: Sending a gift.
36. KÄmrÄn MirzÄto Saheb Ekthiar (then Minister of Justice): Asking him not to sign the court decision concerning Mohammad until he seems him.
37. Hajib-od-Dowleh to Amin-od-Dowleh: Informing him about Naser-ed-Din's (the Shah's) arrival at Anzali.
38. An envelope on which is written: "Two papers with the handwriting of Motamed-os-Saltaneh are presented".
39. Mutamed-os-Saltaneh to Gavame Hozuz (dated 1330 A.H.): Concerning a country estate.
40. Mirza Ali-Asghar Khan Atabak (Chancellor) to the Shah: Complaining about the minister of War and his intrigues.
41. Moshir-od-Dowleh to Azed-os-Saltaneh: Concerning the regulation of the army in Azerbaidjan.
42. Amir Azam to Dr. Qizil Ayaq: Sending him 50 tumans.
43. Ein-od-Dowleh to Dr. Qizil Ayag: Saying farewell before leaving Tehran.
44. A table written by Sani-od-Dowleh: Some political, commercial and geographical information of different countries.
45. The same: The comparison of the measurements of different countries.
46. Abdul Hossein Farmanfarmaian to Dr. Ghani: Sending him the money for his bill.
47. A letter addressing Nazem-od-Dowleh (Persian Ambassador in Turkey): Concerning postal exchange between Iran and Turkey.
48. Fatholla Khan Sheibani (addressee unknown): Requesting a picture.
49. Mohammad Hassein Foroughi: A piece of handwriting.
50. Fatholla Khan Sheibani (addressee unknown): Greetings and compliments.
51. Haji Pir Zadeh to Farhad Mirza: Greetings and compliments.
52. Fatholla Sheibani to Haji Pir Zadeh: Thanking him for a picture and discussing the state of affairs in France.
53. Addressee is Mirza Abdol Vahab Asef-od-Dowleh: The letter is written for Prince Navab Azed-od-Dowleh. Regretting that he cannot be present at a party.
54. Dabir-ol-Molk to Amin-od-Dowleh: Informing him of his (Amin-od-Dowleh's) appointment to the chancellorship and the arrival of the Shah to Anzali.
55. Mirza-Abol-Qassen (poet) to Farhad Mirza: Concerning the loss of several donkeys with loads of wheat.
56. Reza Veqar (poet) to Farhad Mirza: Requesting the rent of a village.
57. The same: Complaining of his illness.
58. Reza Quli Hedayat: A list of the rulers of Mazanderan
59. Molla Nazar Talegani (a famous clergy) to (addressee unknown) Concerning a divinity student.
60. Amir Kabir (Chancellor during the first years of the reign of Naser-ed-Din Shah to Nasir-od-Dowleh: Making an appointment with him.
61. The handwriting of Mirza Hassan Ashtiani (a famous clergyman) on the margin of a letter concerning a judicial problem.
62a. Farhad Mirza to the Persian Ambassador in Turkey dated 1298 A.H.: Concerning an article printed in "Akhtar" newspaper dealing with astronomy.
62b. Hessam-od-Saltaneh to the Ambassador in Turkey: Greetings and compliments.
63. Shams-ol-Ulema to Sarem-Lashkar: Concerning the sending of a sum of money on account of the harvest.
64. Hosein Malik to Dr. Ghani: Sending him a piece of the handwriting of Malek-od-Tojar and two copies of Hafer.
65. Malek-ot-Todjar to his brother, dated 1329 (A.H.) concerning their private affairs.
66. Sayah Mahallati to (addressee unknown): Concerning the writing of a book.
67. In Re Amir Kabir: Concerning an audience.
68. Same.
69. Same: Concerning the reception of the Turkish envoy and complaining about the harsh behavior of the Russian ambassador.
70. Mirza Aga Khan Nouri (Chancellor) to the Shah: Holiday greetings (on the back of this letter the Shah's handwriting.)
71. In Re Amir Kabir: Private Affairs
72. The Same: Concerning Imam JumÄof Tabriz who had refused to go to the court of the Shah.
73. Davar (then Minister of Finance) to Dr. Ghani, dated 131 [5?]. (A.H.) Concerning the receipt of the order.
74. Davar to Ghani (1315 A.H.): Sending him two letters and requesting him to compare them with the letters in the library of Majlis (parliament)
75. Vosug-od-Dowleh to Dr. Ghani: Thanking him for the receipt of a picture.
76. The Same (dated 1309) (A.H.) New Year's Greeting.
77. Farzin to Dr. Ghani: Concerning the sending of two packs of tea
78. Jiyyed Abdol-Ghani (Dr. Ghani's father) (addressee unknown): Concerning the hospital in Sabzevar
79. Haji Amin-oz-Zarb to Dr. Ghani (1308) (A.H.): New Year's Greetings.
80. An entrance ticket into the Vatican in the name of Dr. Ghani (dated Dec.21, 1924)
81. Mirza Said Khan (minister of foreign affairs) to the Persian Ambassador in Turkey: Concerning the personal relations.

82. Hassan Ali Khan Amir Nezam to the Persian Embassy in Turkey dated 1289: Expressing his gratitude to the Sultan of Turkey for a gift and mentioning Shah's dissatisfaction with the scandal in Khan-Valedeh. (in Istanbul)
83. Writer and addressee unknown: Remittance of two hundred tumans for Iranian Consul General in Egypt.
84. Mohsen Khan to the Persian Embassy in Turkey dated 1279: Description of his arrival in Trapuzan.
85. Mutamed-od-Dowleh to the Persian Ambassador in Turkey, dated 1298 (A.H.) Concerning the complaint of merchants about the Consul General in Istanbul.
86. Zel-os-Soltan to Man-al-Folk, dated 1298 (A.H.) Concerning the complaints of the Iranian merchants about the Persian Consul General.
86a. His?m Al-sult?n to Mu c?n Al Mulk
86b. Amin-os-Soltan to (addressee unknown) dated 1308 (A.H.): Concerning
86c. Amin-os-Soltan to Ala-os-Saltaneh (Persian Minister in London) dated 1309. (A.H.) Concerning the activities of Malkan Khan and Liyyid Gamal-od-Din against the Persian government in London.
87. Mohammad Ali-Shah (Shah of Iran after his abdication from throne): Complaining about the late arrival of money.
88. Ahmad Qavam to Dr. Ghani: Concerning the construction of a hospital in Lahidjan.
89. Writer unknown to Saheb Jam: Complaining of illness
90. Haji Mohtashem-os-Saltaneh to Dr. Ghani: An invitation to his house.
91. Ali Soheili (then minister of foreign affairs) to Dr. Ghani: Expressing condolences.
92. Malek-ol-Mutakkalemin (a famous revolutionary and writer): An interpretation of a few verses of the Koran.
93. Abol Hassan Djelve (a poet) to Abdol Ali Mirza: Concerning the book of Alfiyeh.
94. Nazem-ol-Atteba to Aqa Usof, the merchant: Requesting him to send 100 tumans.
95. Nazem-ol-Atteba: A note on Persian grammar
96. The Same: Notions on historical and medical problems.
97. The Same.
98. The Same.
99. The handwriting of Haji Mulla Hadi Sabzevazi (A famous Persian philosopher): Concerning the donation of two days water supply to divinity students.
100. The minister of foreign affairs' agent in Khorassan to the ministry: Concerning the personal affairs of Mirza Hosein Khan.
101. The handwriting of Sabuzi Esfahani (a contemporary poet)
102. Jiyyid Nasrolla Taqavi to Dr. Ghani: Recommendation for Dr. Alavi.
103. Ali Khan Zahir-od-Dowleh (Governor of Mazanderan) dated 1278 (A.H.).
104. Nazem-ol-Atteba: A note about Ali-ebne-Abbass (a 4th century physician)
105. Kazemzadeh Iranshahr to Dr. Ghani (May 27, 1938): Thanking him for the book of Avicenna.
106. Pirzadeh to the Shah: Requesting monetary help.
107. The marriage certificate of Amir Azam and Esmat Khanom.
108. Haji Molla Sultan Ali Gonabadi to Hosein Ali Shirazi: Informing him of the receipt of a book.
109. The handwriting of Haji Aqa Mohammad Najm Abadi. (a famous mujtahed).
110. Malek-al-Kalam: Some poetry
111. Moin-od-Dowleh Sheibami: some poetry
112. Iradj Mirza Jalal-ol-Molk (a famous poet of the period of Persian revolution): some poetry
113. Malek-ol-Kolam Sharqi: some poetry
114. Mirza Hosein Khan Badi (a poet): poetry
115. Vahid Dastgerdi (poet): some poetry
116. Tului Araqi (poet): poetry
117. Sorushe (poet): poetry
118. Ghomam Hamadani (poet): poetry
119. Ebrat Naim (poet): Poetry (page from a book)
120. Adib Beizai Kashani (poet): Poetry
121. Malek-ol-Kalam Shargi (poet): Poetry
122. Adib Beizai Kashani (poet): Poetry
123. Aqa Sheikh Hadi Birjandi to (addressee unknown): Concerning his poetry.
124. Sorush (Poet): poetry.
125. The handwriting of Aqa Hosein Nadjm Abadi
126. Aqa Sheikh Hadi Birjandi to (addressee unknown): Concerning his biography.
127. Nasyr Divan Fozuni Kermanshahi: some poetry
128. Mirza Nemate Rouzani to (addressee unknown): Concerning his family affairs.
129. Sheikh Ahmad Shalroodi to Amir Azam: Concerning the necessity of preventing the export of wheat.
130. The Same: Concerning the plight of some tradssmen.
131. Siyyid Hassan Modarres to(addreseee unknown): Recommending two persons as candidates for the Parliament.
132. Ebrahim Khan Samiáº½to Mohammad Hassan: Concerning the management of his estates.
133. Karim Dad Khan Nardini to Mirza Mehdi Khan Birjandi: Concerning a lot of land in Birjand.
134. Sho-os-Saltaneh (Mohammad All Shah's brother) to the minister of Court: Concerning the sale of a garden.
135. Firuz Mirza Nosrat-od-Dowleh to his son Mozaffar Firuz: Inquiring after his health and that of his family.
136. Sho-os-Saltaneh to the Minister of Court: Concerning the sale of a garden.
137. Mostofi-ol-Mamalek to the Crown Prince: Concerning Ehtessab-ol-Molk.
138. Mostofi-ol-Mamalek to (addressee unknown): The same.
139. Orders concerning the working days of the employees of the various sections of the court in Azaraijan.
140. Esmail Khan Momtaz-od-Dowleh to (addressee unknown): Concerning family affairs.
141. Writer unknown to Haji Sad-od-Dowleh: Concerning some orders given to Molla Bashi
142. The handwriting of Haji's Sheikh Hadi: The sura of Ankabut from the Koran.
143. Not identified.

144. The letter from Dr. E. Brown to Mohammad Kazem Khorassani, dated 1329 A.H. Concerning the danger of the rivalry between the Bakhtiari and Qashqai tribes and asking Khorassani to advise the tribes to stop the rivalry.
145. Mirza Aqa Khan Nuri (Chancellor) to Aziz Khan Sarda: Concerning the signing of a secret treaty between Iran and Russia.
146. A letter of Aqa Khan Nuzi to Aziz Khan Sardar: Concerning the same treaty.
147. Mohammad Kazem Khorassani: In reply to an inquiry concerning the necessity of the Parliament in Iran.
148, 149 and 150. The treaty between Iran and Russia concerning the neutrality of Iran during the Russo-Turkish War.
151. Mirza Ali Khan Amin-od-Dowleh (Chancellor) to Naser-ed-Din Shah: Criticizing the administration of the government.
SERIES II

152. A translation of the telegram of the English Foreign Minister to the English Minister in Tehran, dated 1325: Concerning the invasion of the Persian borders by the Ottoman army and the discussion on this score with the Russian ambassador in Istanbul.
153. English Minister in Tehran to Farmanfarma, dated 1325. A translation of two telegrams received from London, are being sent (Concerning the border problems between Iran and Turkey.)
154. Farmanfarma to Mohammad Ali Shah presenting a rug and 500 Tumans.
155. An order of Naser-ed-Din Shah, dated 1268, concerning the appointment of Sultan Murad Mirza to the governorship of Khorasan.
156. A piece of the handwriting of Teimurtash: Concerning the question of justice.
157. A piece of handwriting of Farmanfarma vowing friendship to Amin-od-Dowleh if he will remain loyal to Mohammad Ali Shah and the Qajar dynasty.
158. A piece of handwriting of Abul Qasem concerning a philosophical problem.

159. Farmanfarma to his wife Ezatod-Dowleh: Sending a message to Mohammad Ali Shah via her, advising the Shah to be more careful in giving his orders and complaining that the Shah is so busy with people that there is no time to discuss secret problems with him.
160. Mossadeq-os-Saltaneh (Dr. Mossadeq) to Farmanfarma concerning the court situation of Mohammad Ali Shah and the Parliament.
161. The rest of the above letter.
162. A telegram of Amin-os-Soltan to Farmanfarma--dated 1325(A.H.): Concerning the appointment of Farmanfarma to the governorship of Azarbaijan.
163. Mohammad Ali Shah to Haji Mirz Rafi Khan, dated 1325 A.H. saying that he has left all his furniture in Azarbaijan to Farmanfarma.
164. Mohammad Ali Shah to Farmanfarma saying that the furniture was given to him as a gift and money was expected, but since he has sent some, it will be accepted.
165. An order of Mohammad Ali Shah dated 1325 A.H. concerning the appointment of Farmanfarma to command of the Zuleh tribe.
166. An order of Mohammad Ali Shah, 1325 (A.H.) concerning the appointment of Farmanfarma to the Ministry of Justice.
167. An order of Mohammad Ali Shah, 1325 (A.H.) concerning the appointment of Farmanfarma to the Governorship of Azarbaijan.
168. Reza Shah to Feridoon Jam (his son-in-law) dated 15 Khordad 1322 A.H. criticizing the character of Persians.
169. A copy of the concession for the construction of highways and railroads in different parts of Iran to Ein-od-Dawleh, Moshir-od Dawleh, and others.
170. Mohammad Hassan Mirza (heir to the throne) to Farmanfarma concerning an incident on the Turkish border.
171. A piece of Farmanfarma's handwriting concerning his loyalty to Mohammad Ali Shah and the Qajar dynasty.
172. Zel-os-Sultan to Farmanfarma--dated Shaval, 1324 A.H.: Complaining of illness and stating his decision to go to Europe.
173. A letter from Ommul Khaqan (Mozafar-ed-Din Shah's wife) to Farmanfarma (her son-in-law) reproaching him for leaving his wife at home and marrying women in other places.
174. Ommul Khaqan to Ezat-os-Saltaneh (her daughter and Farmanfarma's wife) Concerning a transaction and other family affairs.
175. An order of Naser-ed-Din Shah, dated Moharram, 1268.
176. A piece of handwriting of Mohammad Taqi Mirza-od-Dowleh (Naser-od-Din Shah's brother): several Arabic verses.
177. Hassan Ali Khan Garusi addressed to his brother recommending Abdul Ali Niknam and requesting the return of his property.
178. Mirza Abol Qasem Qaen Maqam addressee unknown--Expressing gratitude for being remembered.
179. Ron-od-Dowleh to Naser-ed-Din Shah.
180. The same. Concerning the marriage of his son Nasrullah Mirza with Sharaf-od-Dowleh.
181. Written by unknown to Heshmat-od-Sultan the mayor of Quchan. Concerning the city's affairs and borders.
182. Foroughi Zoka ol Mulk to Dr. Ghani sending him several books.
183. Mirza Ali Khan addressee unknown complaining that he is out of favor and stating that he is ready to hand in Governments accounts.
184. Mozaffar-ed-Din Shah to Rok-od-Dowleh (in his handwriting). Asking about his health.
185. Ein-od-Dowleh to Qaen-Maqem ol-Molk Rashti (Rafi) on the occasion of the death of Shariet Madar expressing his condolences.
186. The secretary of the heir to the throne to Rafi dated 17 Shahrisar 1306. Concerning the health and the education of the prince.
187. Kam-ran Mirza to Rafi--Expressing condolences on the occasion of the death of Shariet Madar.
188. Shor-os-Soltaneh (Mohammad Ali Shah's brother) to Rafi: Expressing his sorrow on the illness of Rafi and discussing the situations arising from the war.
189. Sad-od-Dowleh to Rafi: Concerning the suit of Mokhber-os-Soltaneh and his nephews.
190. Sam-Sam-os-Soltaneh Bakltia to Rafi concerning the presentation of his views to the members of the Cabinet when they meet.
191. Zahir-od-Dowleh to Rafi: Recommending Yazdan Verdi Khan.
192. Sepahdar to Rafi: Expressing his friendship.
193. Taymurtash to Rafi--Recommending Mirza Mohammad Khan.
194. Ala ol Mulk to Rafi--Concerning a leave for his son.
195. Sepahsalar TonKaboni to Rafi expressing friendship.
196. Sepahsalar to Rafi--the same.
197. Saad-od-Dowleh to Rafi: Concerning the ruling of the court on his financial affairs.
198. Kamran Mirza to Rafi: An invitation to dinner.
199. Sepahdar to Rafi: In reply to Rafi's complaint about the telephone conditions between Tehran and Te
200. Sepahsalar to Rafi expressing condolences on the death of Shariet Madar.
201. General Abdullarh Khan Tahmasebi addressee unknown. Concerning slanderous rumors about Mahmud Khan.
202. Ein-od-Dowleh to Rafi: Expressing his thanks for the termination of his affairs with the bank.
203. Adl-ol-Mulk to Rafi: A friendly letter.
204. Asef-od-Dowleh Salehi to Rafi: Complaining of his affairs and the lack of concern of the members of the government for him.
205. Abdullah Khan Amir Tahmasebi to Rafi: Concerning the steps taken for the construction of roads and general improvements in Azerbaijan.
206. Rules and regulations of the Cabinet, dated Rajab 1314 A.H., signed by Muzaffar-ed-Din Shah.
207. Asef-od-Dowleh to addressee unknown. Complaining that no one is concerned about him.

208. A printed announcement by Kuchek Khan concerning the appointment of Khalu Qurban as his deputy and as the chief of a detachment of the Red Army of the Republic (Rise of Kuchek Khan in Mazanderan against the central government.)
209. Mirza Mohammad Khan Sepahsalar to Mirza Aqa Khan: Explaining the demands of Mirza Mohammad Ali Kahn for 1200 tumans.
210. The decision of the Cabinet, signed by Mozaffar-ed-Din Shah: Concerning the export of rice from Gilan, to Europe.
211. A piece of handwriting of Qavam-od-Dowleh: Concerning the mills of Tarasht.
212. Sahib Ekltiar to Kamran Mirza: An invitation to a party.
213. An order for the appointment of Mohammad Taher Mirza to Governorship of Qarejeh Dagh, sealed by Mirza Said Khan, minister of foreign affairs, dated Rabi-os-Sani, 1262.
214. The handwriting of Amin-od-Dowleh, concerning the establishment of a special assembly named the assembly of nobles, signed by Mozaffar-ed-Din Shah.
215. Mohammad Hasan Mirza Valiahd (Crown Prince) to Saheb EkhtiÄr 4 Saratan (Cancer) 1303 A.H., complaining of dizziness and requesting his speedy return.
216. Haj Sheykh Abd-al-Karim, to Rafi: A note of thanks.
217. Same to Same. Asking to transmit a message to the Shah.
218. Same to Same. Note of greetings.
219. Ab-ol Hasan Musavi-al EsfÄhÄni to Rafi: Answer to two questions in regard to canon law.
220. Modarres to Rafi: 19 Jamadi-al-ulÄ1242, concerning the situation in KÄshÄn and the likelihood of dissorders in connection with elections.
221. DÄvar to Mowlavi (from Europe), February 14, 1911, complaining about conditions in Iran.
222. Esmail Momtaz al-Dowleh to Mowlevi, 14 Day 1309, concerning sums of money owed him.
223. DÄvar to Mowlavi (from Europe) November 3, 1912. Criticism of conditions in Iran.
224. Order of Mozaffar ed-Din Mirza, Heir to the Throne, to Amid- od-Dowleh Governor of Khoi and Salmas. Shavval 1296. Concerning a local rebel.
225. Mirza Hasan Safi All Shah to (unknown) Greetings.
226. French Ambassador in Constantinople to Mozaffar ed-Din Shah (Translation), congratulating him upon his accession to the throne.
227. Haj Sheykh MortezÄ Ashtiani to (unknown) Greetings.
228. Fakhr-od-Dowleh ShirÄzi to (unknown) Greetings (Excellent example of Persian calligraphy.)
229. Seykh Fazlollah Nuri to (unknown) Concerning the arrest of a merchant In Mashad and a request for his release.
230. Sheykh al-Eraqeyn to (unknown) Congratulations.
231. Haj Mirza HedÄyat Javaheri to (unknown) requesting the return of a ring. On the margin autograph of Mirza Said Khan, Minister of Foreign Affairs.
232. ZorriÄsateyn Shirazi to (unknown) requesting the return of a ring. On the margin autograph of Mirza Said Khan, Minister of Foreign Affairs.
233. Mirza Hashem Ashtiani to (unknown) Invitation to dinner.
234. Haj Seyyed Abol Qasem KÄshÄni to (unknown), recommending Seyyed Abdol Karim the Mojtahed.
235: Mirza Lotf Ali Sadr ol-AfÄzel to (unknown), note of thanks.
236. Shariat MadÄr Rashti to (unknown) Note of thanks.
237. Unknown to unknown. On the margin autograph of Adib PashÄvari, recommending the hiring of Sheykh Ali in the library.
238. Haj Abol Hasan Mirza Sheykh al-Rais from Shiraz to Tehran to (unknown) informing his correspondent of the dispatch of 25 volumes of his books.
239. Haj Sheykh Abdol Karim, Head of the Qom Learned Society (clerical) to (unknown) Recommending Ali Borjuerdi.
240. Haj Sheykh Mehdi Shams ol-OlamÄto (unknown) Note of thanks.
241. AgÄ ZiÄ ArÄki to (unknown) thanking the Ministry of Education.
242. Hojjat ol-EslÄm HÄj AgÄli Akbar Borujerdi to (unknown), concerning an order of the Prime Minister.
243. HÄj Sheykh Mohammad Mazandarani from Karbela to (unknown), concerning royal gifts to be sent to Haydarabad.
244. EmÄm Jom'e of ZanjÄn to (unknown), recommending Ezz-od-Din.
245. Mirza Mohammad Bager Guardian of the Shrine at Qom to (unknown), 18 Day 1317. Greetings.
246. HÄj AgÄ JamÄl EsfahÄni (VÄez) to (unknown). Greetings and complaints about ill health.
247. Letter by unknown author, on the margin the handwriting of Haji Mirza Hadi Dowlet Abad: Concerning the sale somebody's estate.
248. Syyid Hasan Modarres to (unknown) prince Regretting that misunderstanding has occurred.
249. Amin-os-Soltan (chancellor) to the Persian Embassy in Turkey. Dated 1309 A.H. Concerning Jamal-ed-Din and his expulsion from Turkey.
250. Amin-os-Soltan to the Persian embassy in Turkey, dated 1309, A.H. Concerning the demand of subscription fees to Al-Ahram (edited in Egypt.)
251. Mohammad Ibrahim Alam Amir Shoukat-ol-Molk to Dr. Ghani--dated 1321 (solar year)--Greetings.
252. Syyid Mohammad Behbehan? to Dr. Ghani. Recommending Dr. Ehsan.
253. Abdol Mohammad Khan to unknown. Asking salary to be sent to Kurdestan.
254. Mohammad Shah to Qahraman Mirza dated 1257 A.H. Concerning removal of Mohammad Rahim Mirza.
255. Bill of expenditure of the personnel of the stable and the artillery of Khorasam signed by Hesam-os-Soltaneh.
256. Andalib-od-Dowleh to Amin-od-Dowleh concerning the dispatch of letters by Aqa Ali.
